To understand this possibility consider a put option at $20 on a stock with a value
that has decreased to $1. The intrinsic value of the put is $19 so the upside is very
limited, the downside (if the price of the underlying subsequently increases) is
significant, and because no payment will be received until the expiration date, the
current option value reflects the present value of any expected payment. Extending
the time to expiration would decrease that present value. While overall we expect a
longer time to expiration to increase the value of a European put option, in the case
of a deep in-the-money put, a longer time to expiration could decrease its value.
